text: Burundi's electoral commissioner, Pascal Barandagiye, has called for the press to be barred from covering the country's upcoming elections in 2020. The controversial move comes amid growing tensions between the government and opposition parties, who have accused the ruling party of attempting to rig the vote.Speaking at a press conference, Barandagiye argued that the media should not be allowed to cover the elections, as it could "compromise the transparency of the vote." He stated that the media has a "negative impact" on the country's political process, and that it was necessary to "protect the integrity of the election."However, opposition parties have accused the ruling party of trying to suppress their message and restrict press freedom. "This is a clear attempt by the ruling party to silence opposition voices and limit the ability of the media to report on the election," said one opposition leader. "The media is essential to a fair and democratic process, and any attempt to restrict it is unacceptable."Human rights groups have also condemned the move, with Amnesty International calling it "a blatant attack on press freedom." The organization's secretary general, Kumi Naidoo, said that "the media plays a crucial role in holding those in power accountable and ensuring that the voices of all Burundians are heard."It remains to be seen how the government will respond to Barandagiye's call, but the move has already sparked widespread condemnation from both local and international actors.

Ukraine's presidential election results have been disputed by opposition candidates who claim the vote was marred by fraud.The election, held on March 31, saw incumbent President Petro Poroshenko concede defeat to opposition candidate Volodymyr Zelensky, a comedian with no prior political experience. However, challenges to the results have been filed by Poroshenko's campaign and another opposition candidate, Yulia Tymoshenko, who finished third in the race.Tymoshenko's campaign alleges that the vote was rigged in favor of Zelensky and has called for a recount. Meanwhile, Poroshenko's team has accused the election commission of misconduct, including the use of fake documents and pressure on voters.The election commission has denied any wrongdoing and has said it will investigate the allegations. The international community has called for calm and urged all parties to respect the results of the election.The developments come amid heightened tensions between Ukraine and its Russian-backed separatist territories in the east, as well as between Ukraine and Russia itself. Zelensky has promised to seek a peaceful resolution to the conflict, but the dispute over the election results could further complicate efforts to stabilize the country.

The European Union has released a report condemning both Georgia and Russia for their actions during the five-day war in August 2008. The report, which was compiled by the European Commission, found that both sides had committed serious human rights violations and war crimes.According to the report, Russian forces committed a range of abuses, including looting, destruction of property, and mistreatment of civilians. The report also criticized Georgia for its disproportionate use of force in attempting to reclaim the breakaway region of South Ossetia.The report called on both sides to hold those responsible for human rights violations accountable, and to take steps to ensure that such abuses do not occur in the future. It also called on the international community to provide assistance to the victims of the conflict.In addition to the human rights abuses and war crimes, the report also criticized both sides for failing to respect the rule of law and the principles of international humanitarian law. The EU has urged both sides to cooperate fully with international investigations into the conflict, and to work towards a peaceful resolution of the dispute.The report has been welcomed by human rights organizations and diplomats, who say that it provides a clear and impartial assessment of the conflict. However, both Georgia and Russia have criticized the report, with Russia claiming that it is one-sided and biased against Russia.

Washington, DC - US lawmakers are pushing for more sanctions on Russia, citing its "menacing behavior" around the world.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell announced on Tuesday that he will work with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to develop new sanctions against Russia. This comes as tensions between the two nations continue to escalate over issues such as Ukraine and election interference."We must take steps to deter Russia's aggressive behavior, including its interference in other countries' elections and its violation of international norms," McConnell said in a statement.The move is supported by both Democrats and Republicans, who agree that Russia poses a significant threat to US national security."We have been too slow to impose consequences on Russia for their bad behavior," said Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina. "We are living in a new world where Russia is trying to break us apart, and we need to take steps to protect our democracy."The new sanctions are expected to target Russia's energy sector, as well as its defense and intelligence sectors. They may also include measures to limit Russia's access to the global financial system.The Trump administration has not yet commented on the proposed sanctions, but it is expected to support the measure. The White House has previously imposed several rounds of sanctions on Russia over its actions in Ukraine and interference in the 2016 US election.The US has been trying to build a coalition of nations to impose sanctions on Russia, but some countries, such as Germany, have been hesitant to impose harsh penalties on Russia.The US lawmakers' move comes as tensions between the US and Russia continue to escalate.

"Amidst the ongoing conflict in Syria, many children have been forced to flee their homes and seek refuge in neighboring countries. Girard's impressive display of power and precision in the ring secured him a unanimous decision and the prestigious title.This is the first world title for Girard, who has been a professional boxer since 1999. The 31-year-old Girard had to endure months of intense training to prepare for this fight, and his hard work paid off.The WBA light-heavyweight title has been held by some of the greatest boxers in the sport, and Girard is proud to join that list. TOKYO, Feb 1 (Reuters) - Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi named Yoriko Kawaguchi, a veteran politician and former health and welfare minister, as Japan's new foreign minister on Friday.Kawaguchi, 55, is the first woman to hold the post, which has been vacant since Koizumi took office in April last year.As health and welfare minister, Kawaguchi pushed through a law to regulate funeral and cremation services, and was credited with improving Japan's troubled medical and nursing care systems.Kawaguchi will have her work cut out for her, as Japan grapples with tensions with North Korea and China, as well as a slowing economy.Kawaguchi is widely respected within the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and is seen as a moderate who could help smooth ties with Japan's neighbors and cement ties with the United States, which is Japan's most important ally.Kawaguchi takes over from diplomat Makiko Tanaka, who resigned after a gaffe-prone stint in which she upset Japan's Asian neighbors with comments about the country's wartime past.

WASHINGTON, July 18 - The US envoy to Sudan said on Thursday that he would seek to expand the scope of the Comprehensive Peace Agreements signed by Sudan and southern rebels earlier this year."We are seeking to make the peace more comprehensive, to bring more people into the process," said the envoy, Cornelius "Cob" Wyckoff, in an interview with Reuters.Wyckoff said he would seek to broaden the peace deals, which ended two decades of civil war between the government and rebels in the south, to include other regions of the country that have suffered from conflict."There are other areas of Sudan that are in need of peace, and we want to make sure that peace is extended to them," Wyckoff said. "We believe that the CPA offers a framework for resolving conflicts in other parts of the country."The envoy said that the US would work with other international partners, including the United Nations, to support the implementation of the peace agreements and promote reconciliation and healing in Sudan."The international community has a role to play in helping to bring stability and peace to Sudan," Wyckoff said.

The European Union has announced that its peacekeeping forces are prepared to intervene in Bosnia-Herzegovina if new tensions arise between the country's ethnic groups.The statement comes after the EU's High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Catherine Ashton, visited the region and met with top officials from Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia.Ashton said that the EU's Stabilisation and Association Process for the Western Balkans was making progress but cautioned that "we still have a long way to go".She added that the EU was determined to support the peace process in Bosnia and was prepared to use all available means to do so.The announcement has been welcomed by Bosnia's leaders, who have been struggling to keep the country's fragile peace intact.The EU's peacekeeping forces have been deployed in Bosnia since 2004, and their presence has been credited with preventing a return to violence in the country.However, tensions have been rising in recent months between Bosnia's Muslim, Croat and Serb communities, raising fears of a new outbreak of violence.The EU's readiness to intervene if necessary is seen as a significant signal of its commitment to maintaining peace and stability in the region.

Kabul, Afghanistan - Insurgent violence has flared up once again in Afghanistan, with several deadly attacks targeting civilians and government officials over the past week.The latest violence began with a suicide bombing in Kabul on Sunday, which killed at least 16 people and wounded more than 30 others. The attack targeted a convoy of foreign troops, but many of the casualties were civilians who were nearby.The following day, insurgents attacked a government security compound in Kandahar, killing at least six soldiers and wounding several others. The attackers reportedly used a car bomb to breach the compound's gates before engaging in a gun battle with security forces.On Wednesday, another suicide attacker struck in Jalalabad, killing at least 19 people and wounding over 50 others. The attack targeted a security checkpoint, but again, many of the casualties were civilians.The violence has continued despite ongoing peace talks between the Afghan government and Taliban insurgents, which are aimed at bringing an end to the 18-year conflict. The talks have reportedly made some progress, but there are still many sticking points, including the issue of foreign troop withdrawal.Meanwhile, Afghan President Ashraf Ghani has condemned the recent spate of insurgent violence, calling on the Taliban to respect the ceasefire and enter into a permanent peace agreement."We call on the Taliban to stand by their commitment to the ceasefire and to not allow their fighters to carry out these senseless attacks that only cause harm to the Afghan people," Ghani said in a statement.The violence has once again highlighted the fragility of the situation in Afghanistan, where insurgent attacks are a daily occurrence. Despite the ongoing peace talks, many fear that a lasting peace in the country may be elusive, and that the conflict could continue for years to come.

Philippine soldiers have killed three members of the communist New People's Army (NPA) in a clash in the southern province of Surigao del Sur.The encounter took place on Tuesday in the village of Dalag, according to a report from the military's 4th Infantry Division.The report said the troops were conducting a security patrol when they encountered the NPA rebels, who were reportedly planting landmines in the area.A firefight ensued, resulting in the death of three NPA fighters and the injury of another, the military said.The military said it recovered two AK-47 rifles, a shotgun and a hand grenade from the scene of the encounter.The NPA is the armed wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP), which has been waging a guerrilla war against the government for decades.The government has been implementing peace talks with the CPP to end the conflict, but the negotiations have been beset by setbacks and breakdowns in recent years.The incident in Surigao del Sur is the latest in a series of clashes between government troops and the NPA in the southern Philippines.The military has stepped up its operations against the NPA in recent months, citing the need to end the group's violent activities and protect the community.The government has also been encouraging rebels to surrender and rejoin society, offering them amnesty and other incentives.The NPA is listed as a terrorist organization by the government and some foreign countries, although it claims to be fighting for the rights of the poor and marginalized in society.

A new report has revealed that being an MP is the most dangerous job in Africa and Asia.The report, which was compiled by the Institute for Economics and Peace, looked at the levels of political violence and instability in different countries around the world.According to the report, MPs in countries such as Somalia, Afghanistan, and Yemen are at the highest risk of violence. In these countries, MPs are often targeted by extremist groups or criminal organizations because of their position.The report also found that other professions, such as journalists, doctors, and aid workers, are also at high risk of violence in some countries.However, the report notes that there are significant differences in the levels of violence and instability across different regions and countries.For example, while being an MP may be one of the most dangerous professions in Africa and Asia, it is generally considered to be a safe profession in countries such as Canada and Sweden.The report concludes that political violence and instability are major challenges for many countries around the world, and that efforts should be made to improve security for MPs and other professionals at risk of violence.In some countries, such as Somalia and Afghanistan, this may require significant reforms to the political and security systems, the report says.Overall, the report provides a valuable insight into the challenges faced by MPs and other professionals in different parts of the world, and underscores the importance of improving security and reducing violence in these countries.

WASHINGTON - The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must strengthen its oversight of state drinking water programs, an internal watchdog said in a report published on Wednesday. The report came after a water crisis in Flint, Michigan, where the city's drinking water became contaminated with lead in 2014.According to the report, the EPA's Office of Water, which is responsible for overseeing state drinking water programs, did not effectively oversee the Flint water crisis. The office failed to identify and address risks to public health and the environment in a timely manner, the report said."We found that EPA's Office of Water failed to recognize and respond to the severity of the Flint water crisis in a timely manner," the report said. "Specifically, the office did not effectively use its regulatory authorities to provide technical assistance, conduct enforcement activities, or provide emergency funding to support the City of Flint's drinking water efforts."The report recommended that the EPA improve its risk management processes and increase its engagement with states, tribes and local governments to identify and address risks to drinking water systems.The EPA should also develop a system to track and respond to drinking water emergencies in real-time and increase its transparency and communication with the public, the report said."EPA should take a more proactive and collaborative approach to working with states, tribes, and local governments to identify and address drinking water risks," the report said. "By doing so, the agency can better protect public health and the environment and prevent future drinking water crises like the one in Flint."

Congress Reviews Bioterrorism RiskWashington, D.C. - October 11, 2001 (NYSE) - The United States Congress is currently reviewing the potential risks associated with bioterrorism and the country's preparedness to combat any future attacks.The review comes after the recent anthrax attacks that have left several people ill and several others dead. The attacks have heightened awareness of the potential dangers of bioterrorism and the need for effective measures to combat it.Senator Joseph Lieberman, chair of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, stated that the review is necessary to ensure that the country is adequately prepared for any future bioterrorism attacks. "We must ensure that our government agencies are working together effectively, and that we have the necessary resources and plans in place to respond quickly and effectively to any potential bioterrorism threat," he said.The review will examine the roles and responsibilities of various government agencies in dealing with bioterrorism, as well as the adequacy of current funding and resources. "We must be vigilant and take all necessary steps to prevent and respond to any potential bioterrorism attacks," he said.The review is expected to be completed within several months.

The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA) has issued a plea for funds to continue its vital work in providing aid to Palestinian refugees.The agency, which has been providing assistance to Palestinian refugees since 1949, faces a significant funding shortfall, putting its operations and the well-being of the refugees it serves at risk."UNRWA is confronting a severe funding crisis that is affecting our ability to provide essential services to Palestinian refugees in Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, and the West Bank and Gaza Strip," said the agency's Commissioner-General, Pierre Krähenbühl.UNRWA provides education, healthcare, and housing assistance to over 5 million Palestinian refugees. Its work is more critical than ever, given the ongoing conflict in the region."Palestine refugees are among the most vulnerable populations in the Middle East, and they need our support now more than ever," Krähenbühl said.The agency is urging governments and the public to come forward with financial support to ensure that it can continue its vital work.The United States, a major contributor to UNRWA, has recently announced a significant reduction in its funding to the agency, adding to the financial uncertainty faced by UNRWA."We hope that all those who have supported UNRWA in the past will continue to do so and that new partners will step forward to help us deliver assistance and protection to Palestine refugees," Krähenbühl said.The UNRWA Commissioner-General emphasized that the needs of the Palestinian refugees are growing, and the agency must be able to rely on predictable and sustainable funding to continue its vital work."

"A team of international surgeons recently visited Rwanda as part of a mission to provide reconstructive surgery to people in need. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), there is currently only one plastic surgeon for every one million people in Rwanda, making it difficult for many to receive the surgical care they need.The team of international surgeons, who were joined by their Rwandan counterparts, worked at the University Teaching Hospital in Kigali, performing surgeries on patients of all ages. Bhutan and the Maldives have successfully eliminated measles, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced on Thursday.The WHO Verifiable Task Manager (VTM) had reported in June that both countries had not had any new measles cases since the last outbreak in 2016 and 2017, respectively.According to the WHO, the two countries achieved this milestone through high-quality vaccination coverage and strong surveillance systems.Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that can cause serious health complications, including pneumonia, diarrhea, and encephalitis. The disease can also lead to death in some cases.The WHO has been working with member states to control and eliminate measles globally. The organization recommends that all countries ensure that at least 95% of their population is vaccinated against measles to prevent outbreaks.Bhutan and the Maldives are the latest countries to achieve this goal, and their success shows that eliminating measles is possible even in low-income countries with limited resources.The WHO congratulates both countries on this achievement and encourages them to continue surveillance to ensure that the virus does not re-emerge.The organization also calls on other countries to redouble their efforts to achieve the same goal and prevent the spread of measles globally.
